questions.question: The girl looked at her brother and smiled.
questions.description: A compound sentence consists of two or more coordinate clauses. Clauses connected by and, but or or are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: Janet went to the library to borrow some books.
questions.description: The given sentence has just one finite verb and one clause. Infinitives are non-finites.

questions.question: The water was so cold that we could not swim in it.
questions.description: So…that… is a subordinating conjunction. A clause introduced by a subordinating conjunction is a subordinate clause.

questions.question: The little girl started crying when she couldn’t find her toy.
questions.description: 'When' is a subordinating conjunction. Clauses introduced by subordinating conjunctions are subordinate clauses.

questions.question: I live in a large city.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: As soon as the bell rang, the children rushed out.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: We saw a film which was based on the life of Nelson Mandela.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: His crude remarks offended me.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: Jane and Alice had their dinner and went for a walk.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses. Two clauses connected by ‘and’ are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: The boys and the girls were shouting loudly.
questions.description: The given sentence has just one clause. Therefore it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: The customers were happy because they got what they wanted.
The meeting was held in a room near the library.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.
